title: Machine Learning with Python using scikit-learn
speaker: Kartik Mandaville
about_speaker:
Kartik Mandaville currently works on SpringRole - a machine learning based recruiting agency. He also serves as the Senior Technical Advisor at Science in Santa Monica, California. He graduated from Carnegie Mellon University with Masters from the Language Technologies Institute focusing on Big Data, Machine Learning, NLP and BioTech.

Kartik co-founded SpringRole in 2014. SpringRole has a current network of over 85M passive candidates. SpringRole has notable investors backing - Science, Bloomberg Beta and high profile angels.

Science employs a 'studio' model to create, scale, and acquire digital businesses out of our shared space in Santa Monica. As the director of technology, he worked with early stage startups to architecting out their technology, building the team and scaling. He built the Science India team having 25+ software engineers and product working across the portfolio companies.
description:
Topics to be covered in the talk:

- Introduction to ML
- Problem Setting
- Supervised and unsupervised
- Setup for Scikit
- Loading a dataset
- Training a model
- Testing the model on unseen data
- Classification
- Regression

title: The Road to an Open Source contributor (V)
speaker: Ratnadeep Debnath
about_speaker: Ratnadeep Debnath, AKA, rtnpro has been contributing to the Open Source community since 2010. Currently, he works as a container engineer at Red Hat and is using Golang in his day job. He has contributed to many Open Source projects including Mozilla, Transifex, Wikimedia and Fedora. He is  the creator and maintainer of Waartaa, an open source communication and collaboration tool for humans.
description:
This talk will take the audience through my journey of becoming an Open Source contributor. 

This talk will try to explain how to start Open Source contributions by contributing, rather than traditional course studies. 

This talk will also describe the various projects I have been involved with and my drive for it and what I learnt from it.

In short, this talk will help the curious listeners to be inspired to kickstart their Open Source journey.

title: Working with Flask Framework
speaker: Flicksys Inc.
description:
- Introduction to Python Flask
- Client Server Model
- Designing RESTful APIs with Python and Flask

title: Pycoin
speaker: Projjol Banerji
about_speaker:
Projjol has worked extensively on web platforms and is a regular contributor to the Mozilla Foundation. 
LOTR, Star Wars and FOSS maniac, he loves to build great software | Hack it, ship it.
description:
Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency that intends to solve the problem of having middle-men in financial transactions or banks. It allows individuals to transfer money to each other without having an intermediary source snooping in on their private transaction. 

Bitcoin's rebellious notions put aside the real ground breaking tech that has emerged from it is the blockchain. The blockchain is central to the concept of Bitcoin as all transactions that occur over the Bitcoin network are post validation stored in the blockchain. 

The height and longevity of the blockchain for any currency is a testament to the legitimacy of initial transactions. The talk is going to revolve around the central concept of the blockchain and a PoC implementation in Python.

title: Using Django with MongoDB
speaker: Rakesh Kumar
about_speaker: Founded Eudoxia Technolgies( now Softgators Tech Pvt Ltd ) in 2013 with a vision to provide world class software services which is now a very well known company for it's better services and 98% client satisfaction.
description:
Django with MongoDB using MongoEngine

- Web development with Django and MongoDB

- What is Django, Architecture, model classes

- Forms, Views

- MongoDB, Document Model, Denormalization, Nested Queries

- Comparison with RDBMS

- Django with Mongo, Mongo Engine Model

- Collecting things in View, Connecting to Database

- When should you use MongoDB

title: Anomaly Detection
speaker: Shreya Khurana
about_speaker: A math nerd who's passionate about cricket, she has always had fun playing with numbers - be it the stats of a match scoreboard or the digits on a vehicle number plate. She is a firm believer in the power of data and a big fan of social entrepreneurship. A math and IT grad, she started working as a Data Scientist with EcoZen Solutions a couple of months back.
description:
From constant monitoring of data using Excel and analyzing countless graphs to developing statistical models to automate the whole procedure, we’ve come a long way in our approach to detect anomalies in processes.

Ever wondered why a cardiologist spends hours looking a patient’s medical history? Or why banks keep an extremely detailed track of their users’ transactions? Time series data provides an answer to how your regular processes should behave and why in some bizarre cases they do not.

This talk will be about how machine learning models are now being used to predict when the next anomaly will occur and whether the current data seems to suggest an anomaly that we’ve encountered before, with a special focus on supervised learning.

I will give examples of how this is taken up by various industry sectors and explain how the same algorithms can be applied to sophisticated applications like handwriting and speech recognition. In specific, I will explain how the manufacturing sector uses data science techniques in order to give their processes and products an edge over the others.

This talk will also explore basic visualization and preliminary data analysis techniques, specific to this context, and you may see some bouts of extreme devotion towards Pandas because well, let’s admit it, that library is GOD.

The structure of the talk will be as follows:

- Intro to Anomaly Detection + Applications
- Time series analysis
- Algorithms currently in use
- Python libraries used
- Code demo a. EDA: Basic techniques b. Fault detection
- Pre-requisites

Basic stats, ML and Python knowledge
Love for Pandas (the library)

title: Become a pdb power-user
speaker: Ashwini Chaudhary
about_speaker:
Ashwini works at Instamojo as a software engineer. He has been using and contributing to Python for almost over 5 years now. From building a scalable payment system to end-to-end cutting edge applications for Wall Street.

He currently ranks #1 for Python on Stack Overflow in India! Apart from programming, he loves travelling on his bike and playing FIFA.
description: This talk focuses on the effective general and power usage of the interactive python debugger.

title: Mission Control in Mars - Extraplanetary Python (V)
speaker: Mario Tambos
about_speaker:
Mario is a machine learning enthusiast, who has recently made a change in career from backend development to machine learning and data science.

A veteran developer, he has experience in a wide range of programming languages such as .Net, Java, PHP, C and Perl; in diverse environments like web application development and Service Oriented Architectures.

He has also had experience in leading teams of developers, using ISO process methodologies, for the Argentinean National Spatial Activities Commission (CONAE), and Scrum, for Teracode BA and Intel, among others.
description: In this talk I'll talk about the experience of trying to develop open source software for the space industry, the advantages of using Python for the purpose, and the GSoC program.

title: Python with Oculus Rift and Leap Motion Controller
speaker: Aakash Rajpal
about_speaker: Aakash Rajpal, is a final year C.S undergrad at Manipal. He was introduced to coding in his first year and was attracted to Python because of its simplicity. Since then, he's been a part of FOSSEE Manipal and has interned as a Python Dev at IIT Bombay. He  successfully finished his GSoC project on Virtual Reality under Python Software Foundation. He strongly believes in giving back to society and is one of the founding members of Teach Code For Good, an organization that teaches Python to underprivileged students. Apart from Coding, he loves Football and is an enthusiastic traveler.
description: The project involved developing an interactive Heads up Display (HUD) on the OCULUS RIFT for the V-ERAS Simulation (VR simulation of the Eras Mars Station). Once the interactive semi-transparent interface is implemented on the existing V-ERAS simulation environment it should display data from the Habitat Monitoring Client. The Habitat Monitoring Client GUI is already in place. The GUI needed to be integrated with the blender game engine which runs the simulation through blender python API. The Habitat Monitoring Client can interface with any general Tango Device Server. This Device Server could be any Sensor placed on the Mars environment. The HMC could get a request from the user to poll a specific server and get the average, minimum or maximum of the values. A portion of the project was aimed at making the HUD highly interactive and recognize touchless hand and body gestures through Leap Motion Controller. The Leap Motion Controller is able to detect Hand gestures. The Leap motion controller (LMC) will be integrated with Blender through the Leap Motion API for Python which will result in controlling simulation in Blender Game Engine (BGE) using hand movement gestures. There are four standard gestures recognized by the Leap Motion software through the Gesture Class in its Python API. The Leap API for Python will communicate with the Blender API for Python (bpy) to feed the data from the LMC server into the BGE so that the simulation of V-ERAS can be controlled through the Leap Motion Controller using gestures.

title: Sentiment Analysis using Word2Vec
speaker: Shubham Goel
about_speaker: A machine learning enthusiast, Shubham loves playing around with data. He's an ardent Arsenal supporter who in his free time is found binge-watching TV shows or playing football.
description: The talk aims at using Word2Vec, which allows words to be represented in the form of vectors, to help predict the sentiment of a movie review.
